skill.name: executing-epic-workflow
skill.description: Execute systematic feature development using EPIC methodology (Explore, Research, Plan, Validate, Implement, Review, Iterate). Use when building features, implementing complex tasks, or following structured development workflows. Delegates exploration, research, planning, validation, and review to specialized agents.
skill.summary: Execute systematic feature development using EPIC methodology with specialized agent delegation
skill.author: Emz1998

security_audit.summary: All 157 static findings are false positives. The scanner misinterpreted markdown documentation backticks as shell execution commands, dictionary configuration access as environment variable exposure, and benign text patterns as weak cryptographic algorithms. No actual security risks found.

content.value_statement: Building complex features without a structured approach leads to scope creep, missed requirements, and technical debt. The EPIC workflow provides a systematic seven-phase methodology that delegates to specialized agents and enforces completion validation at each step.
actual_capabilities: Orchestrates seven-phase development workflow (Explore, Research, Plan, Validate, Implement, Review, Iterate)
Delegates exploration, research, planning, validation, and review to specialized subagents
Enforces phase completion validation through automated script checks
Creates session directories for organized artifact management
Tracks implementation progress using TodoWrite tool with real-time status updates
Ensures strict plan adherence with iterative compliance flow until validation passes
limitations: Does not execute code or modify files directly outside the implementation phase
Relies on user-provided context and requirements for feature specification
Cannot make architectural decisions without research and planning phases
Main agent implements directly but follows pre-defined plans from specialized agents

use_cases.title: Complex feature development for enterprise applications
use_cases.description: When building features that require deep codebase understanding, research into best practices, and careful planning, the EPIC workflow ensures nothing is missed. The main agent delegates exploration and research to specialized agents, creates a comprehensive implementation plan, validates it with a consulting expert, then implements with full context.
use_cases.target_user: Senior developers and engineering leads building multi-component features

use_cases.title: Onboarding to unfamiliar codebases
use_cases.description: When joining a new project or needing to understand a large codebase, the Explore phase systematically documents the current state, dependencies, and related features. This creates a knowledge base that the main agent uses throughout development.
use_cases.target_user: New team members and developers unfamiliar with existing codebases

use_cases.title: Risk-averse implementation of critical systems
use_cases.description: For payment systems, authentication modules, or other high-stakes code, the Validate phase provides objective review of the implementation plan before any code is written. This catches over-engineering and identifies risks early.

prompt_templates.title: Basic EPIC workflow initiation
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the executing-epic-workflow skill to build [feature description]. Follow the full EPIC methodology: Explore the codebase, Research best approaches, Plan the implementation, Validate the plan, Implement the feature, Review the code, and Iterate on feedback.
prompt_templates.scenario: Starting a new feature with minimal context

prompt_templates.title: EPIC workflow with existing context
prompt_templates.prompt: Execute the EPIC workflow to implement [feature]. The relevant files are in [path]. Start with Explore phase to understand current implementation, then proceed through Research, Plan, Validate, Implement, Review, and Iterate.
prompt_templates.scenario: Continuing work on an existing feature

prompt_templates.title: EPIC workflow with scope constraints
prompt_templates.prompt: Run the executing-epic-workflow skill to add [specific functionality]. Constraint: Stay within the existing architecture patterns documented in the codebase. Follow Explore, Research, Plan, Validate, Implement, Review, Iterate but flag any scope creep for user approval.
prompt_templates.scenario: Implementing features with strict scope boundaries

prompt_templates.title: Full EPIC workflow with integration requirements
prompt_templates.prompt: Execute the EPIC workflow to build [feature] that integrates with [external system]. Use codebase-explorer to map current architecture, research-specialist to investigate integration patterns, strategic-planner to design the approach, consulting-expert to validate, then implement with TodoWrite tracking throughout.
prompt_templates.scenario: Complex integrations requiring multiple specialist inputs

best_practices: Start with clear feature requirements and acceptance criteria before initiating the EPIC workflow
Allow adequate time for exploration and research phases - thorough context gathering prevents rework
Review validation feedback from the consulting-expert phase before implementation begins
anti_patterns: Skipping phases to rush to implementation - this defeats the purpose of structured development
Providing vague feature descriptions that require clarification mid-workflow
Proceeding to the next phase when validation fails instead of iteratively retrying

faq.question: What is the main agent responsible for in the EPIC workflow?
faq.answer: The main agent handles implementation directly (Phase 5) and orchestrates the workflow. All other phases (Explore, Research, Plan, Validate, Review, Iterate) are delegated to specialized subagents with explicit instructions to save reports to the session directory.

faq.question: What happens if phase validation fails?
faq.answer: The workflow enforces iterative compliance. If validation fails, the main agent must reinvoke the responsible subagent with explicit instructions to create the missing required file, then re-run validation. This repeats until validation passes before proceeding.

faq.question: How are session directories organized?
faq.answer: Session directories follow the pattern .claude/sessions/[NN]-[session-description]/ where NN is a two-digit sequential number. Each phase produces specific required files (codebase-status.md, research-report.md, implementation-plan.md, etc.) saved to this directory.

faq.question: Can I skip phases in the EPIC workflow?
faq.answer: No. The EPIC methodology requires completing all seven phases in sequence. Skipping exploration, research, or validation leads to incomplete context, uninformed decisions, and implementation errors that require costly rework.

faq.question: What tools does the main agent use during implementation?
faq.answer: The main agent uses TodoWrite for task tracking (one task at a time, real-time status updates), Read for accessing session artifacts, Write/Edit for code implementation, and AskUserQuestion for clarification when uncertain.

faq.question: How does the workflow ensure quality?
faq.answer: Quality is enforced through multiple checkpoints: consulting-expert validates the plan before implementation, test-engineer reviews test coverage during review, and iteration phase addresses all feedback until final verification passes.
